RT @PaulDEaton52 But our troops usually use single shot, not burst fire.                     You’re able to fire a much more accurate (deadly) shot, that way. Note: you can buy our Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight on Amazon. So troops usually select the same fire option available on AR-15.  6/

RT @PaulDEaton52 But even now, you can buy AR-15s in variable barrel lengths with Weaver or Picatinny rails for better sights and aiming assists like lasers. Like the military, but w/o the bayonet. 5/

RT @PaulDEaton52 So what’s the difference between the military’s M4 and the  original AR-15?                                                   Barrel length and the ability to shoot three round bursts. M4s can shoot in three round bursts. AR-15s can only shoot single shot.  4/

RT @PaulDEaton52 The military began a transition from the M16 to the M4, an improved M16, some years ago.                                               The AR-15 is essentially the civilian version of the M16.                             The M4 is really close to the M16, and the AR-15.       3/

RT @PaulDEaton52 Those opposed to assault weapon bans continue to play games with AR-15 semantics, pretending there’s some meaningful differences between it and the M4 carbine that the military carries.                                          There really aren’t.                        2/

As the Chair of the Higher Education Subcommittee, I believe that higher education is a RIGHT for all, not a luxury afforded by the few.

We need to address the #StudentDebtCrisis head-on, but we also need to provide comprehensive solutions to fix these institutional failures.

The benefits of student debt cancellation are life-changing and have the potential to lift many folks out of intergenerational poverty.

When we #CancelStudentDebt, we open the possibility for financial security for countless future generations of families.

Racial & gender equality should remain goals for our nation, and pathways to achieve them can begin with canceling student debt.

When we #CancelStudentDebt, it will remove a barrier for millions to reach their highest economic potential and secure a brighter future for all.

If you think cancelling student debt for others is unfair because you paid yours, consider this: Cancelling student debt is good for the economy.
This can have a powerful stimulus effect for everyone, boosting our GDP and creating even more new jobs.

For years, we have encouraged students to work hard and pursue higher education. We promised them that if they continued their academic engagement, they would receive the coveted college degree and achieve unbounded success.
They followed our guidance, but now they need help.

First, it’s critical to understand exactly what the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) does and doesn’t do. It doesn’t *store* gasoline, but reserves of largely light sweet and sour crude that can be used to make gas for our cars.

The mess Biden created by his improper, nonsensical use of our emergency oil stockpile - the Strategic Petroleum Reserve - was entirely predictable. It was the action of a flailing administration trying to undo the damage of its own policies.

Kaylee and Dolly are people I would probably never talk to if I didn’t do this walk. But they raise real issues that will inform the way I think about, and vote on, housing policy and trade policy.

Dolly owns a salon and has noticed recently that the care products she imports from China have been causing infections for her clients. So she has switched to American made products. She wonders why there isn’t more scrutiny of Chinese imports.

Kaylee is in subsidized housing and pays 25% of her income in rent. But she’s getting married, and the housing authority is upping her rent bc of the double income. But the net result is both she and her husband will pay a greater % of income in rent. A true “marriage penalty”.

Want to tell you two stories of people I met in Naugatuck - both examples of how this walk impacts the way I think about policy.

I send my condolences to the families of those killed and am praying for the full recovery of everyone suffering, both physically and emotionally. Again, we will never forget, and we will ensure that the memory of those murdered will forever be a blessing.
I am heartbroken for the families and loved ones touched by this senseless tragedy. I share the pain of my community and know this pain will not subside.

I will seek to end the trafficking of guns across state lines. I will continue to promote investment in our nation’s mental health, in particular supporting more services for our young people still struggling from the impact of the pandemic.

I will do everything in my power to get military-style assault weapons off our streets and out of our communities. I will work to restrict access to large-capacity magazines that allow a shooter to fire 80 rounds in less than a minute.

Congress last month passed – and President Biden signed – the Bipartisan Safer Communities Act. The House has twice passed legislation requiring universal background checks, among other bills. But we must do more, much more.

Next week, when I return to Washington, I will redouble my  commitment to addressing the evil scourge of gun violence in our country. Monday’s mass shooting was the 308th in the country this year. These shootings are ending lives, destroying families, and devastating communities.
Highland Park is strong, and we are thankful to be supported by our neighbors and friends both near and far. We will heal, and we will recover, but we will never forget.

In the days ahead, 7 families will focus on saying a final goodbye to their loved ones. Others will begin the process of recovering from physical wounds. All of us will lean on one another to work to heal the emotional trauma each of us are experiencing in our own distinct way.

Immediately after the shooting, I did what I could to help people to safety. I ensured my team members were secure. I reached out to other local leaders to offer the services of my office for whatever they might need.

In an instant, that sense of joy was shattered by a deranged man who acquired weapons of war, climbed to a rooftop, and fired more than 70 bullets into the crowd below. While his motive is unknown, his intent was clear: kill as many people as possible, as quickly as possible.

I normally walk in five parades each year. Highland Park was to be the second of the day. My campaign team was gathering at the start of the parade as the crowds along the route were festively celebrating being back together again after two years of COVID cancellations.
Here in Illinois and across the country, the July 4th is a time when communities gather to celebrate our country’s birth, our freedom, and the ideals that define us as a nation.

As Highland Park continues to grieve, I want to express my personal thanks to all who reached out with care and concern following the July 4th shooting that killed seven loving individuals, wounded at least 30 others, and changed the lives of everyone across our region.

Without dark money, we’ll finally be able to see real conflicts of interest. Here’s where judicial ethics reform comes in, whether the justices do it themselves (fat chance) or Congress takes action via my Supreme Court Ethics, Recusal, & Transparency Act.

How to fix what’s wrong at SCOTUS? The capture of the Court was enabled by dark money – it funds judicial lobbying groups, moves cases through lower courts, & funds ads for the chosen justices. We can start with transparency: pass my DISCLOSE Act & expose that influence.

My staff has years of experience dealing with the VA and has returned over $300,000 in owed benefits to 8th District veterans. If you’re having an issue, just give us a call at (517) 993-0510 or visit our website at http://slotkin.house.gov – we’re here to help.

We also heard about issues with benefits claims, including denials and delays. While there is still work to be done to streamline the system, my office has dedicated caseworkers that can help vets navigate the process.

The good news is that Congress is set to pass the Honoring Our PACT Act, which includes my Veterans Burn Pits Exposure Recognition Act. This landmark bill will finally cut the red tape needed to get veterans suffering from toxic exposure the care they’ve earned.

We covered a lot of ground, but one common concern was care for veterans suffering from toxic exposure due to burn pits. This is the Agent Orange of the post 9/11 generation, and it’s unacceptable that affected vets have had to fight to get the specialized treatment they need.

Today was about hearing directly from our veterans, so this afternoon, @SecVetAffairs, @SenStabenow & I sat down with vets from across the district to answer questions & listen to their concerns. No media, no audience – just some straight talk about benefits, services & care. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FXGNoXZWYAATrlY.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FXGNoXXX0AMV-oh.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FXGNoXcWIAA7IEh.jpg
